Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Four Star Fruit has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Four Star Fruit, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Four Star Fruit has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

West Process                 Anhydrous Ammonia                71,000

East Process                 Anhydrous Ammonia                39,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1.

Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Descriptions



Facility Layout



Four Star Fruit operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes in Delano, CA. The facility has two independent ammonia refrigeration systems that provide refrigeration capacity to the following:



Process 1 - West System

(13) Rooms

(6) Precools

(3) Hallways

(1) Shipping Dock

(1) Repack Room

(1) Glycol Room



Process 2 - East System

(1) Room

(3) Precools

The flooded system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room, where it passes through an expansion valve into low temperature and pressure accumulator mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, low pressure liquid is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature and pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The suction gas is returned from the accumulators through a suction return line to the main suction accumulator.  From the main suction accumulator, ammonia is piped to the suction inlet on the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water-cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to the high pressure receiver.



The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below estab

lished limits, and pressure relief valves which vent to the ammonia diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point. 



There is an ammonia detector installed inside each refrigeration machinery room. Each sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe. Also, each refrigerated area (e.g. storage room, precool) has a standalone detector installed which provides continuous monitoring. Each refrigerated area detector is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm.



Each refrigeration system has an emergency control box installed which contains three valves. The high and low side of the system each have a valve that would discharge to the diffusion tank. The connecting pipe between the high and low side has one equalizer valve that would equalize each system.



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Four Star Fruit consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping.  As such, each refrigeration system at Four Star Fruit is treated as a separate process.



Process Chemistry



The refrigeration systems employed at Four Star Fruit are flooded systems. In the West System, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds both bunker mounted and ceiling suspended evaporator coils located throughout the facility in cold rooms, packing rooms, hallways, and shipping docks. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the ev

aporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulators. 



The system also includes direct expansion (DX) ceiling suspended evaporator coils. In DX evaporators, high pressure liquid is supplied from the high pressure receivers directly to the evaporators. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporators. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporators and is returned to the main suction accumulators.



In addition to the evaporator coils, the system includes a plate and frame heat exchanger. Low temperature liquid is piped from one flooded accumulator to the plate and frame heat exchanger where it flows through the channels in the plates and absorbs the heat from the water/glycol mixture on the opposite side of each plate. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which returns to the supplying accumulator and is piped back to the main suction accumulators. 



Any remaining liquid in the main suction accumulators falls to the bottom of the vessels and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receivers as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulators, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the conden

sers. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers. The receivers serve as holding tanks for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 



In the East System, high pressure liquid from the high pressure receivers is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds several bunker mounted evaporator coils located in cold rooms throughout the facility. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any remaining liquid in the main suction accumulator falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receivers as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.



The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes

within the condensers. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receivers. The receivers serve as holding tanks for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 

 

Safety Systems

There is an ammonia detector installed inside each refrigeration machinery room. Each sensor is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm and strobe. Also, each refrigerated area (e.g. storage room, precool) has a standalone detector installed which provides continuous monitoring. Each refrigerated area detector is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate visual and audible alarms.



Each machinery room is equipped with a roof-mounted emergency ventilation fan that automatically activates at a certain setpoint. The emergency ventilation systems can be controlled manually by the ON/OFF switch and HAND/OFF/AUTO switches located outside the West and East Machinery Rooms. 



The Emergency Control Boxes were installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2 and the Fire Code at the times of construction. The control boxes each contain three (3) valves.



Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. The Emergency Control Boxes are seldom used in refrigeration systems, but have been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves. The

high side of each system relieves at 250 psig while the low side of each system relieves at 200 psig or 150 psig. All pressure relief valves  for both systems are piped to the diffusion tank.



Each main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.

 



Process Classification



Each ammonia refrigeration system at Four Star Fruit consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Four Star Fruit are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Four Star Fruit has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Four Star Fruit facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the proce

ss is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment.  



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Four Star Fruit has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Four Star Fruit's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Four Star Fruit has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Four Star Fruit continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Four Star Fruit's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Four Star Fruit's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

Four Star Fruit has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed,

the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Four Star Fruit has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Four Star Fruit now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Four Star Fruit employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Four Star Fruit will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
